section.title: Past perfect
section.sectiontitle: We use the Past perfect to link one time in the past to another time further in the past.
section.text1: First everyone left. Then we got there.
section.text1a: When we got there, everyone had left.
section.text2: I lived in Mexico for six months. Then I met Sonia.
section.text2a: I'd lived in Mexico for six months before I met Sonia.
section.sectiontitle2: We do not usually use the Past perfect when the sequence of events is clear. We use the Past simple.
section.text3a: I had a shower and went to bed.

section.title: Past perfect
section.sectiontitle: In the positive, we use had + past participle. In the negative, we use had + not + past participle. We often use the short forms.
section.text1a: After I'd finished my homework, I watched television.
section.text2a: He was very hungry because he hadn't eaten all day.
section.sectiontitle2: In the question, we use had + subject + past participle.
section.text3a: Had you known Kiera for long before you got married? Yes, I had.

section.title: Past perfect
section.sectiontitle:
With the Past perfect, we use many of the same time words and phrases that we
use with the Present perfect, including for, since, already, just, yet, recently, It was the first/second/third time.
section.text1a: I was very pleased because I'd just passed my driving test.
section.text2a: It was the second time I'd met Gina.
section.sectiontitle2: With the Past perfect, we often use by, by the time, when, after, before and as soon as.
section.text4a: We did the washing up after everyone had gone.
